title: How to Make Bread and Butter Pickles

steps.headline: Cut the cucumbers into ⁄4 inch (0.64 cm) slices.
steps.description: Rinse 1 ⁄2 pounds (0.68 kg) of pickling cucumbers and trim off the ends. Use a sharp knife to cut each cucumber into thin, even slices and put them in a large, shallow bowl. If you don't have a large, shallow bowl, put the pickles in a shallow baking pan.

steps.headline: Toss the cucumbers with salt and refrigerate them for 1 1/2 hours.
steps.description: Sprinkle 1½ tablespoons (31 g) of kosher salt over the sliced cucumbers in the bowl and toss them together. Cover the bowl and put the cucumbers in the refrigerator to chill.Did You Know? Salting the cucumbers and chilling them will draw out moisture so the pickles will be crisp.

steps.headline: Rinse and drain the sliced cucumbers.
steps.description: Set a colander in the sink and remove the cucumbers from the refrigerator. Put them in the colander and run cold water over the cucumbers. Keep rinsing to remove the salt and let the cucumbers drain in the colander. Then put the cucumbers back in the bowl.

steps.headline: Slice sweet onion to toss with the cucumber slices.
steps.description: Get out a sweet onion and peel it. Place it on a cutting board and slice it as thinly as you can. You should get about 1 cup (115 g) of thin slices. Put these in the bowl with the cucumbers and mix them together. Use a mandoline slicer to easily cut the onion into thin, even slices.

steps.headline: Mix the sugars, vinegars, turmeric, mustard seeds, and celery seeds.
steps.description: Set a saucepan on the stove and put 1 cup (200 g) of granulated sugar, ¼ cup (50 g) of light brown sugar, 1 cup (240 ml) of white vinegar, ⁄2 cup (120 ml) of apple cider vinegar, 1½ teaspoons (1 g) of mustard seeds, ½ teaspoon (1 g) of celery seeds, and 1/8 teaspoon (0.4 g) of ground turmeric into it.

steps.headline: Cook the mixture over medium heat until the sugar dissolves.
steps.description: Stir the mixture as it cooks and forms a syrup. You'll need to heat it for about 3 to 5 minutes so there aren't sugar crystals in the syrup. Then turn off the burner. The syrup will bubble gently before the sugar dissolves completely.

steps.headline: Pour the hot syrup over the sliced vegetables and let it stand for 1 hour.
steps.description: Carefully pour the syrup over the cucumbers and onions in the bowl. Leave the mixture to cool for 1 hour at room temperature.

steps.headline: Cover and refrigerate the pickles for 24 hours before serving.
steps.description: Cover the bowl tightly with plastic wrap or transfer the pickles in the syrup to 2 pint jars with lids. Refrigerate the pickles in the syrup for at least 24 hours before eating them. You can store the bread and butter pickles for up to 1 month in the refrigerator.

steps.headline: Sterilize 2 pint jars and prepare a water bath for canning.
steps.description: Place a large stockpot full of water on the stove and place the jars in it so they're submerged. Turn the burner to high so the water comes to a boil and heat the jars for 10 minutes. Turn off the burner and leave the hot water in the stockpot. You'll use this to process the jars of pickles. If you prefer to simply store the pickles in the refrigerator instead of canning them, refrigerate them in sterilized containers for up to 1 month.

steps.headline: Slice the cucumbers and 1/2 of an onion into ⁄4 inch (0.64 cm) pieces.
steps.description: Rinse 3 pounds (1.4 kg) of pickling cucumbers and cut off the ends. Then peel an onion. Cut each cucumber and 1/2 of the onion into thin, even slices and place them in a colander. Set the colander in the sink. To make it easier to cut the cucumbers or onion, use a mandoline.

steps.headline: Toss the vegetables with salt and rest them for 1 to 2 hours.
steps.description: Sprinkle 1/4 cup (68 g) of kosher salt or sea salt over the sliced cucumbers and onion in the colander. Use your hands or a spoon to stir them together and leave them to sit at room temperature for at least 1 hour. The salted cucumbers will release liquid as they sit. Removing this excess liquid will make the pickles crunchy.

steps.headline: Rinse the vegetables and lay them on a sheet.
steps.description: Run cold water over the salted vegetables in the sink to remove the salt. Let the water drain while you line a baking sheet with paper towels. Spread the sliced vegetables on the paper towel-lined sheet.Did You Know? Drying the cucumbers completely will allow them to absorb more of the sweet and salty brine.

steps.headline: Cover the cucumbers with paper towels and refrigerate them overnight.
steps.description: Spread a layer of paper towels over the sliced cucumbers and onions on the sheet. Place the baking sheet in the refrigerator and chill them overnight.

steps.headline: Mix the vinegar, water, sugar, and seasonings in a saucepan.
steps.description:
Put 2 cups (470 ml) of white vinegar, ⁄2 cup (120 ml) of water, and 1 cup (200 g) of granulated sugar into a saucepan along with:
2 tablespoons (22 g) of mustard seeds
1 teaspoon (1 g) of celery seeds
1 teaspoon (2 g) of ground turmeric

steps.headline: Bring the syrup to a boil over medium-high heat.
steps.description: Stir the mixture as the sugar dissolves and becomes syrupy. Cook the mixture until comes to a vigorous boil. Then turn off the burner. It's important to use a medium or large saucepan so the syrup doesn't boil over.

steps.headline: Fill the sterilized jars with the sliced cucumbers and onions.
steps.description: Carefully lift the hot jars out of the water bath and set them on your work surface. Remove the sheet of sliced cucumbers and onions from the refrigerator and fill the jars with the vegetables. Leave ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) of space at the top of the jar. Leaving headspace at the top of the jar will prevent the pickles and syrup from escaping as the jars process.

steps.headline: Pour the syrup over the vegetables and leave ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) of space.
steps.description: Slowly pour or ladle the hot syrup over the sliced cucumbers and onions in the jars. Keep filling so the vegetables are completely submerged. Leave ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) of space at the top of the jar before you seal it shut.

steps.headline: Process the jars for 15 minutes.
steps.description: Set new seals on the jars and screw bands on until they're fingertip tight. Carefully lower the jars into the water bath that you set up earlier. Bring the water to a boil over high heat and then set a timer for 15 minutes. Boiling the jars for 15 minutes will force the air out of the jar and create a vacuum-seal so the pickles are preserved.

steps.headline: Let the pickles rest for 1 to 2 days before eating them.
steps.description: Remove the jars from the water bath and let them cool to room temperature before you store them. For the best flavor, wait 1 to 2 days before opening a jar and eating them. For long-term storage, keep the unopened jars at room temperature for up to 1 year. Once you open a jar of pickles, store it in the refrigerator.
